title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Martha was happy at the thought of passing her days in the Highlands, somewhere in the Glen of Dee, or in Glen Tilt, or on the banks of the Bruar, or by the waterfalls of the Tummel, or the sylvan shores of Loch Bannoch.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We went up to the very highesttop, which cannot be seen from the house orfrom below; and from here the view is like apanorama : you see the Falls ofthe Bruar, Ben-y-Chat, Ben Vrackie, Ben-y-Ghlo, the KilliecrankiePass, and a whole range of distant hills on theother side, which one cannot at all see from below.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The Bruar springs from the skirts of Ben Dearg, or the red mountain,  so called from the red colour of the granite of which it is composed.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In September 1844, Her Majesty sojourned for nearly three weeks at Blair Castle, visiting the Falls of Bruar, the Pass of Killiecrankie, the Falls of Tummel, and the other picturesque scenery with which the neighbourhood abounds.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: — The Tay with its tributaries Lochy and Dochart, Tilt, Bruar, Garry, Tummel, Lyon, Braan, Almond, Ardle, Shee, Ericht, and Isla.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: With some ladies I visited the little falls, as we should call them, of Bruar, celebrated by Burns and other poets, who never saw Niagara.

title: Days of the past;
author: Shand, Alexander Innes
snippet: Rivers like the Tilt or the Bruar were regularly bridged, though the bridges, then as in Scrope's days, would be as regularly washed away in winter, to be brought back and rebuilt in the spring.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: Due allowance, she thought, had been made for the effects of Highland air, but the climb to Bruar, "or the brunt of the weather," had produced an unusual demand.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: It is after a two hours' climb up the glen to see such a waterfall as the Bruar that we return to the coach feeling, as wb mount to our seats, that we have done our duty.

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: Standing on the bridge across the Bruar, one need not be entirely off his balance to sympathize to some extent with the wild wish of my young lady friend, who thought if she had to be anything dead she would be a plunging, mad stream like this, dancing  among the rocks, snatching to its breast, as it passed, the bluebell and the forget-me-not, the broom and the fox-glove, leaping over precipices and tossing its gay head in sparkling rainbow sprays forever and ever.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: [Professor Walker was a native of Ayrshire, and an accomplished scholar ; he saw Burns often in Edinburgh ; he saw him at the Earl of Athol's on the Bruar ; he visited him too at Dumfries ; and after the copyright of Currie's edition of the poet's works expired, he wrote, with much taste and feeling, his life anew, and edited his works — what passed under his own observation he related with truth and ease.]

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: [The Falls of Bruar in Athole are exceedingly beautiful  and picturesque; and their effect, when Burns visited them, was much impaired by want of shrubs and trees. This was in 1787 : the poet, accompanied by his future biographer. Professor Walker, went, when close on twilight, to this romantic scene : " he threw himself," said the Professor, "on a heathy seat, and gave himself up to a tender, abstracted, and voluptuous enthusiasm of imagination. In a' few days I received a letter from Inverness, for the poet had gone on his way, with the Petition enclosed." His Grace of Athole obeyed the injunction: the picturesque points are now crowned with thriving woods, and the beauty of the Falls is much increased.]

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: For, in the grey of the morning, a man from thevillage of Blair came to inform Lord George Murray, that Sir Andrew Agnew,who commanded at Blair Castle, had caught the alarm, from an attack on aneighbouring post; had got a great proportion of his garrison of five hundred menunder arms, and was advancing to the Bridge of Bruar, to see what enemies werein the neighbourhood.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The various detachments set out with eagerness upon an enter-prise which promised to relieve their country or neighbourhood from invasion andmilitary occupation ; and Lord George and Cluny, with only twenty-five men, anda few elderly gentlemen, proceeded to the Bridge of Bruar, being the rendezvous,there to await the success of their undertaking and the return of their companions.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Eachparty was expected to perform the duty assigned to it before daybreak, and allwere then to repair to to the Bridge of Bruar, within two miles of the Castle ofBlair-in-Athole.
